Population Models in MarS

Overview

MarS supports three physically distinct population models for simulating EPR spectra:

  1. Thermal equilibrium - populations follow the Boltzmann distribution.

  2. Kinetic non-equilibrium - populations evolve according to rate (kinetic) equations.

  3. Density-based formalism - full time-dependent dynamics governed by the density matrix formalism.

These models are implemented through dedicated populator classes.

Factorization vs. Non-Factorization

  • Factorizing calculators (mars.spectra_manager.spectra_manager.StationaryIntensityCalculator, mars.spectra_manager.spectra_manager.TimeIntensityCalculator, mars.spectra_manager.wave_calculator.WaveIntensityCalculator) assume the spectral intensity for a transition \(i \leftrightarrow j\) can be written as:

    \[I_{ij} = \underbrace{(p_j - p_i)}_{\text{population difference}} \times \underbrace{|M_{ij}|^2}_{\text{transition matrix element}}.\]

    This approach is valid when coherence between states can be neglected (e.g., in incoherent or high-temperature limits).

  • Non-factorizing calculators (mars.spectra_manager.spectra_manager.TimeDensityCalculator) compute the observable signal directly from the full density matrix without separating populations and coherences:

    \[I(t) \propto \mathrm{Tr}\!\left( \hat{G}_\perp \, \hat{\rho}(t) \right),\]

    where \(\hat{G}_\perp\) is the transverse component of the spin operator (e.g., \(\hat{G}_x\) or \(\hat{G}_y\)), and \(\hat{\rho}(t)\) is the time-evolved density matrix.

Thermal Equilibrium

At temperature \(T\), the equilibrium population of energy level \(k\) is given by the Boltzmann distribution:

\[p_k = \frac{e^{-E_k / k_B T}}{Z}, \quad Z = \sum_\ell e^{-E_\ell / k_B T},\]

where \(E_k\) is the eigenenergy of level \(k\), \(k_B\) is Boltzmann’s constant, and \(Z\) is the partition function.

This model is used by: - mars.population.populators.stationary.StationaryPopulator - mars.spectra_manager.spectra_manager.StationaryIntensityCalculator

It serves as the default for continuous-wave (CW) EPR simulations unless overridden by a custom initial state in a mars.population.contexts.Context (see details in Relaxation Context).

Time-Dependent Kinetics (Rate Equation Approach)

When spin relaxation is treated classically (i.e., ignoring quantum coherences), the time evolution of level populations \(p_i(t)\) follows a system of linear kinetic (rate) equations:

\[\frac{dp_i}{dt} = \sum_{j \ne i} \left( k_{ji} p_j - k_{ij} p_i \right) - o_i p_i,\]

where: - \(k_{ij}\) is the probabilities of transition from level \(i\) to \(j\), - \(o_i\) represents irreversible loss (e.g., phosphorescence from triplet sublevels)

Density Matrix Formalism

For systems where quantum coherences matter, MarS solves the Liouville–von Neumann equation for the density matrix \(\hat{\rho}(t)\):

\[\frac{d\hat{\rho}}{dt} = -\frac{i}{\hbar} [\hat{H}, \hat{\rho}] + \hat{\mathcal{R}}[\hat{\rho}],\]

where: - \(\hat{H}\) is the spin Hamiltonian, - \(\hat{\mathcal{R}}\) is the relaxation superoperator.

In MarS, \(\hat{\mathcal{R}}\) can include:

The observable EPR signal is then computed as:

\[I(t) \propto \mathrm{Tr}\!\left( \hat{G}_\perp \, \hat{\rho}(t) \right)\]

Two computational strategies are supported:

  1. Rotating Wave Approximation (RWA) Assumes isotropic \(g\)-tensor and commutation \([\hat{F}, \hat{G}_z] = 0\). The Hamiltonian is transformed into a rotating frame, yielding an effective time-independent problem. Implemented in: - mars.population.populators.density_population.RWADensityPopulator

  2. Full Propagator Method Solves the periodic time-dependent problem exactly over one microwave cycle and constructs the long-time evolution via Floquet-like theory.Implemented in: - mars.population.populators.density_population.PropagatorDensityPopulator

Summary of Populators

StationaryPopulator

  • Computes populations at specified temperature. Uses thermal equalibrium or Context-defined population

  • Default for CW-EPR simulations

LevelBasedPopulator

  • Handles time-dependent populations with kinetic relaxation

RWADensityPopulator

  • Full density matrix computation under rotating wave approximation

PropagatorDensityPopulator

  • Full density matrix computation under computation of evolution superoperator

Custom populators Users may implement new population dynamics by subclassing: - mars.population.populators.core.BasePopulator (for stationary cases) - mars.population.populators.core.BaseTimeDepPopulator (for time-dependent cases)

For more details on polarized spectra, time-resolved modeling, and context-based relaxation specification, see the sections
